thread.title: Trump Supporter Goes On Racist Tirade Against Starbucks Barista For Taking Too Long [Video]
thread.title_full: Trump Supporter Goes On Racist Tirade Against Starbucks Barista For Taking Too Long [Video]

posts.author: Aaron Homer
posts.title: Trump Supporter Goes On Racist Tirade Against Starbucks Barista For Taking Too Long [Video]
posts.text:
A Starbucks customer went on a racist, obscenity-laden tirade at a barista who he (the customer) thought was taking too long, invoking Donald Trump in the process, The Miami New Times is reporting .
A Trump supporter went on a racist tirade at a Miami-area Starbucks. [Image via Sergey Kohl /Shutterstock] Jorge de CĂĄrdenas was working at a Miami-area Starbucks Wednesday afternoon, as a long line of customers was waiting, when a white customer took exception to how long his order was taking. Jorge says the man screamed “Trump!” at a black employee, then said his order was taking so long because of “anti-white discrimination.” He then either called the employee “trash” or “garbage” – Fox News says the customer called the man “ trash ,” while Miami New Times says he called him “garbage.”
Then the man started getting downright nasty, says de CĂĄrdenas.
“So he started disparaging the staff. One patron called him an a e, so he said, ‘F**k you, b***h.’ That’s when I started filming.”
Jorge then recorded the man continuing his racist tirade. You can see video of the altercation below, but be warned: this video contains strong language that may be offensive to some viewers.
#trump supporter in #miami @Starbucks attacks & threatens patrons & staff bc coffee took too long, blames anti-white “discrimination” pic.twitter.com/HRj9EahrMy 
â€” jorge de cardenas (@Jbdcl) November 16, 2016 
For those who can’t, or won’t, watch the video, here’s what happens: as the man goes about his rant, he asks the barista for her name, again calling her “garbage.” Another customer tries to intervene.
“Come on. There’s no need to talk like that. You want to talk like that, take it outside. But do not talk to other people that way.”
The two men continued arguing – de CĂĄrdenas says they “almost came to blows” – and then the man stormed out.
The Trump voter who went on the racist tirade has since been identified, and he spoke to The Miami Herald to give his side of the story. David Sanguesa says that he was just having a bad day .
“I had a bad day. I was wrong for screaming at her. I have since apologized.”
As the Herald notes, it seems like Sanguesa has had more than his share of bad days. In 2008 he had two DUI’s within a matter of days. In 2014 he was hit with domestic violence charges, which were later dropped. The Herald also notes that Sanguesa has a history of emailing the newspaper about topics that interest him, and usually those topics include disparaging Cubans, women, immigrants, gays and lesbians, President Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. In one email, Sanguesa claimed that Obama had cost 95 million jobs (that’s about 64 percent of the American workforce , according to Job Economics , and no, unemployment is not now, nor has it ever been, at 64 percent).
US economy added 161000 jobs in October as unemployment rate dipped to 4.9 perce… https://t.co/XSiSrb55T3 #econ pic.twitter.com/TVHdHLOmgJ 
â€” Aleks Kins (@aleks_kins) November 5, 2016 
Meanwhile, Sanguesa says he is considering a lawsuit; against whom it’s not clear, but he seems upset with de CĂĄrdenas for only presenting one side of the story.
“No one saw the first part of the video. I was completely done wrong. I was racially discriminated against. I was refused service. I was wrong to get upset, but I was racially discriminated against. [The Starbucks barista] wouldn’t serve me. She knew I was a Trump supporter and wouldn’t give me my coffee.”
Jennifer Santos, the barista, denies that she refused to serve him because he was a Trump supporter.
In a statement, Starbucks, while not addressing the altercation directly, did point out that diversity among its customers and employees is something that the company values.
Jorge de CĂĄrdenas, for his part, believes the angry Trump supporter had no reason to get upset in the first place.
“The funny thing, besides just the concept of ‘anti-white discrimination,’ is just yelling ‘Trump!’ for no reason. Like, dude, you won.”
[Featured Image by Sorbis /Shutterstock]
Trump Supporter Goes On Racist Tirade Against Starbucks Barista For Taking Too Long [Video] is an article from: The Inquisitr News

thread.title: This is How Millions of Trump Fans are Punishing Starbucks?

posts.author: Susan Wright
posts.title: This is How Millions of Trump Fans are Punishing Starbucks?
posts.text:
So this is odd. And hilarious.
When Starbucks CEO, Howard Schultz endorsed Hillary Clinton, Trumplings across the country unleashed their drooling outrage.
This week, they have taken to social media… and their local Starbucks… to get a taste of their “revenge.”
They are ordering their coffee, lattes, and other assorted caffeine-bombs by giving the name “Trump” to be scrawled across their cups.
I encourage everyone to get #Trump on their cup! Post a pic of it here on Twitter to @Starbucks with #Trumpcup https://t.co/vcwqWlPhTG 
— Amy Noelle (@NoelleTMD) November 18, 2016 

I’m the Muslimah who put @realDonaldTrump on my @Starbucks cup! #TrumpCup 
Trump is MY President! pic.twitter.com/A9Ylm2sK80 
— MaryKhalaf (@MaryiamKhalaf) November 18, 2016 

The move has inspired a social media hashtag: #TrumpCups .
The effort garnered more widespread attention this week after video of a Florida man yelling “I voted for Trump!” and berating a Starbucks worker made its way online and quickly went viral. The man, who called the barista “trash” and “garbage,” said in an interview with The Miami Herald . “She knew I was a Trump supporter and wouldn’t give me my coffee.”
On Friday, Twitter users were encouraging others to join in on the write-in effort.
It’s an awesome way to show Starbucks who’s boss, alright.
No. Really.
As one Twitter user pointed out:
Wow, the irony of millions of Trump supporters going to Starbucks and buying coffee to punish Starbucks. Unbelievable. #TrumpCup Go get ’em!
— Kelly Challis (@kechallis) November 18, 2016 

I am absolutely laughing at this, and now I need my iced caramel Frappuccino.

"If someone is getting so triggered, they can't write Trump on a coffee cup at Starbucks and they're crying liberal tears and they're calling the cops, that's insane."

Starbucks told Business Insider that the coffee chain does not require employees to write or call out names provided by customers.Â 
"Over the years, writing customer names on cups and calling out their names has been a fun ritual in our stores," the coffee giant said in a statement. "Rarely has it been abused or taken advantage of. We hope and trust that our customers will continue to honor that tradition." 
The inspirationÂ for the Trump Cup movement stems from a video posted on Twitter onÂ November 7 of a man asking for employees to write "Trump" on a cup. thread.title: Trump Supporters Protest Starbucks by Spending More Money at Starbucks
thread.title_full: Trump Supporters Protest Starbucks by Spending More Money at Starbucks

posts.author: Virginia Chamlee
posts.title: Trump Supporters Protest Starbucks by Spending More Money at Starbucks
posts.text: Trump Supporters Protest Starbucks by Spending More Money at Starbucks That’ll show ‘em Nicola/Flickr Supporters of President-elect Donald Trump, angry with Starbucks for supporting a liberal agenda, are protesting the Seattle-based coffee chain — by visiting locations across America and buying coffee there. The protesters are using the hashtag #TrumpCup to instruct followers to place their Starbucks orders using the name "Trump," thereby forcing the barista to write the name on a coffee cup and yell it out once an order is ready. As CNN reports , the movement gained traction after a video showing a white Trump supporter at a Miami Starbucks accusing a barista of racial discrimination went viral on Thursday. The man, who can be seen pacing throughout the store and demanding his money back, begins yelling "I voted for Trump! You lost!" because his coffee is apparently not made fast enough. He then threatens to punch a fellow customer (who told him not to speak to people that way), though he leaves pretty quickly after the man says he’d be happy to "take it outside." The hashtag #TrumpCup isn't new, per CNN, but it has found a renewed following after the video’s release. Some have claimed the coffee chain will "call the cops" if one uses the name "Trump" to order a drink, offering a video (which never actually shows police officers coming to Starbucks) as proof. It is worth noting, of course, that the logic behind the "protest" — which isn’t much of a protest at all — is deeply flawed, as it requires throwing financial support behind the very target of the protest. And yet, Trump supporters, including actor Scott Baio, continue to take to Twitter, proudly sharing photos of the drinks they’ve purchased at the chain they claim to hate: 1) Go to Starbucks & tell them your name is Trump2) If they refuse take videoPls share & spread the word pic.twitter.com/huPj4g6cqY — Baked Alaska™ (@bakedalaska) November 18, 2016 If we want Trump written on our cups don't call the cops! Feel free to boycott Starbucks after this. Even Kanye wants to #MAGA ! #TrumpCup pic.twitter.com/YyFv96dhz0 — Irma Hinojosa (@latinaafortrump) November 18, 2016 Check out this! @realDonaldTrump I've started the "give the Trump name" #TrumpMovement pic.twitter.com/7cGSgCSaTH — Scott Baio (@ScottBaio) April 4, 2016 The new protest takes a bit of heat off Starbucks for its seasonal red cups, which have been mired in their own controversy . Last year, a Christian internet evangelist wearing a Jesus Christ shirt and toting a handgun argued that the chain’s red cups weren’t Christmasy enough. He fought back by imploring his followers to use the name "Merry Christmas" when ordering their beverages. So, if you’re mad at Starbucks — a chain worth some $50 billion — be sure to visit your nearest location, wait in line, spend $5 on a coffee, and take a photo of it. That’ll show ‘em.

thread.title: Trump supporters have started a protest of Starbucks that involves... buying more Starbucks

posts.author: Anna Swartz
posts.title: Trump supporters have started a protest of Starbucks that involves... buying more Starbucks
posts.text:
Trump supporters have started a protest of Starbucks that involves... buying more Starbucks 
Trump supporters have launched a protest against Starbucks that, oddly enough, brings more business to Starbucks. 
Trump supporters have started #TrumpCup, a viral campaign to force Starbucks employees to say "Trump," CNN reported on Friday . The "movement" is apparently a response to a viral video which surfaced this week of a Florida man screaming "I voted for Trump!" at a Starbucks barista who didn't make his drink fast enough — and then accusing the staff of discriminating against him for being white. 
It's not clear what, exactly, the #TrumpCup folks are protesting, but it seems as though quite a few diehard Trumpians have marched into their local Starbucks stores to demand a #TrumpCup of their very own.

The apparent irony of "protesting" a company (for what reason, again?) by giving them more of your money hasn't gone unnoticed by people on social media. Even fellow Trump supporters have tried to point out the nonsensical nature of trying to hurt Starbucks by patronizing Starbucks.

This isn't the first time Starbucks has become a lightening rod for people who feel as though the company is a bastion of liberal values. Last year, the company's season red cups caused outrage amongst people who felt they represented an attack on Christmas because they were missing the tradition snowflake designs. The #TrumpCup "protest" is just the latest in a bizarre culture war against the coffee behemoth — but in this case, it just seems misguided, not to mention a missed opportunity to use the hashtag #StarCucks.

posts.text:
A man at a Florida Starbucks was caught on video yelling “Trump” and blaming “anti-white discrimination” for not getting his coffee more quickly on Wednesday.
The Miami Herald reported that Jorge de Cárdenas posted a video on Twitter at 5 p.m. Wednesday that showed a man at a Starbucks near the University of Miami yelling at an employee after he said his wait for his coffee was too long. During the 2-minute video, the man is seen asking for his money back before insulting the employee.
>> Read more trending stories
“You’re trash,” he said to the female cashier, according to the Herald. “'Cause I voted for Trump. Trump. You lost, now give me my money back. You’re garbage. You’re complete trash.”
Cárdenas told the Miami New Times that the man blamed the delayed coffee on “anti-white discrimination.” "He said it was 'anti-white discrimination,'" he said. "So he started disparaging the staff. One patron called him an (expletive), so he said, '(Expletive) you, (expletive).' That's when I started filming."
Cárdenas said the other customer told the man that “there’s no need to talk like that” and said he should “take it outside,” the New Times reported. Cárdenas said the two men “almost came to blows.”
The Herald has since talked to the man , David Sanguesa, 53, who said he was having a bad day. The Herald noted that was just Sanguesa's latest bad day, writing that he had "one in 2008 when he was arrested on a DUI charge. The one a week later when he was again charged with DUI. And the day in 2014 in when he was charged with domestic violence, which was later dropped. And there were all those days, going back years, when he emailed the Miami Herald with rants against Cubans, women, immigrants, gays and lesbians, President Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton."

posts.text:
Donald Trump Supporters Are Saying Their Name Is Trump At Starbucks And Taking Video If Baristas Refuse To Serve Them Clem Email 
The Hill- Latte-loving fans of President-elect Donald Trump may not be willing to give up Starbucks, but they’re putting his name on their drinks. Trump supporters had objected when Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz endorsed then-Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, and the president-elect has slammed the chain’s plainspoken, non-religious holiday cups, suggesting a boycott last year. Now, Trump backers are giving his name to baristas to mark their orders with their support. The move has triggered the hashtag #TrumpCup to soar in popularity. 
The effort garnered more widespread attention this week after video of a Florida man yelling “I voted for Trump!” and berating a Starbucks worker made its way online and quickly went viral. The man, who called the barista “trash” and “garbage,” said in an interview with The Miami Herald. “She knew I was a Trump supporter and wouldn’t give me my coffee.” 
Oh shit, the people are Starbucks must be fucking PISSED that all these people are going to buy a shitload of expensive coffee in order to make some sort of a protest in Donald Trump’s name. The sales projections are probably…well they are probably going through the roof if that’s the case. I can’t imagine what happens when you mix a hashtag and a political matter like this. Actually I can imagine. 
Trending Twitter Hashtag 
Political Statement 
We have people will to act like mannequins in order to support a hashtag. Starbucks is going to be racking in the fucking dough this holiday season, regardless of what colors their cups are. And it’s not like Starbucks is this holier than thou organization. They were Trump in some peoples’ eyes before Trump was. I mean they were one Dr. Evil’s corporations when Austin Powers came out a billion years ago for Christ sake. All this is doing is making Starbucks more powerful than any of us can ever imagine. 
And I don’t really even have a dog in the fight. I think if you ask for any name other than your own at Starbucks, you are a loser. And if you refuse to say the name Trump because you don’t like Donald Trump, you are a loser. Then again, I guess the real losers in this are the people that don’t give a fuck about either side and will have to wait on Starbucks lines that are somehow even longer than they usually are. 
However, if Starbucks employees continue to refuse service and the Trump people post it on the internet, we all kinda win. Because moments like this are what keeps the internet’s lights on. Clem

posts.author: Alberto Luperon
posts.title: Trump Supporter Says He Might Sue Starbucks over ‘White’ Discrimination
posts.text:
Trump Supporter Says He Might Sue Starbucks over ‘White’ Discrimination by Alberto Luperon | 4:00   
Florida man and Trump supporter David Sanguesa went viral on Wednesday when video showed him losing his temper at a Miami Starbucks. Now he’s threatening a lawsuit, saying he was given slow service because he voted for President-elect Donald Trump . 
Video captures Sanguesa losing his cool as he demanded a refund. #trump supporter in #miami @Starbucks attacks & threatens patrons & staff bc coffee took too long, blames anti-white “discrimination” pic.twitter.com/HRj9EahrMy 
— jorge de cardenas (@Jbdcl) November 16, 2016 
“You’re trash,” he said, after having stepped into an employee area. 
“So what?” the woman said. 
“Because I voted for Trump,” he said. 
He demanded a barista’s name, and the employees argued with him over his behavior. He said the barista did discriminate against him. 
“I’ll punch you out,” Sanguesa said to a male employee. 
“You want to go outside?” that male employee said. “I’ll happy to.” 
53-year-old Sanguesa apologies for the incident in a Thursday interview with the Miami Herald , saying he was having what he called a “bad day.” 
“I was wrong for screaming at her. I have since apologized.” But a follow up interview is hinting that this might have long-term legal consequences for Starbucks. He’s lost business because of the viral video, he said. 
“My attorneys want to file a lawsuit,” he said. “No one saw the first part of the video. I was completely done wrong. I was racially discriminated against. I was refused service. I was wrong to get upset, but I was racially discriminated against. 
“She wouldn’t serve me. She knew I was a Trump supporter and wouldn’t give me my coffee.” 
The barista, Jennifer Santos , told WPLG that no, she didn’t refuse him service. 
“He must have been having a bad day,” she said. “I felt disrespected. Very disrespected. It was very insulting and very discriminating. Things happen.” 
We reached out to Starbucks for comment on the viral video, and possible lawsuit. 
“Embracing diversity and treating each other with respect and dignity is core to Starbucks values and something our partners take great pride in showing. We are committed to providing an inclusive, supportive and safe work environment for everyone,” a spokesperson told us. The statement did not mention the possible lawsuit. 
This isn’t Sanguesa’s first run with possible legal actions. From the Miami Herald story: 
Previous bad days: the one in 2008 when he was arrested on a DUI charge. The one a week later when he was again charged with DUI. And the day in 2014 when he was charged with domestic violence, which was later dropped. And there were all those days, going back years, when he emailed the Miami Herald with rants against Cubans, women, immigrants, gays and lesbians, President Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. 
[Screengrab via WPLG]

posts.text:
Trump supporters are making a stand against Starbucks by spending money on coffee in the chain's shops and demanding baristas write "Trump" on their cups.
The movement — which comes to you by the hashtag #TrumpCup — accelerated Friday following an incident in a Miami branch of the coffee chain.
A white supporter of the President-elect was filmed earlier this week shouting at employees, complaining of racial discrimination and telling everyone in the store he voted Trump. The incident kicked off thanks to a delay in the making of his vanilla latte.
#trump supporter in #miami @Starbucks attacks & threatens patrons & staff bc coffee took too long, blames anti-white "discrimination" pic.twitter.com/HRj9EahrMy
— jorge de cardenas (@Jbdcl) November 16, 2016
Trump supporters have had issues with Starbucks for some time. Some of the causes of anger have been the company's CEO Howard Schultz endorsing Clinton and the roll out of its less festive designs, which even triggered a call for a boycott from Trump himself.
On Thursday, a fan going by the name Baked Alaska on Twitter seized the moment to kick start Operation #TrumpCup, with two simple rules. First, go to Starbucks and tell them your name is Trump. Second, film the incident if they refuse to write "Trump" on the cup.
Operation #TrumpCup
1) Go to Starbucks & tell them your name is Trump
2) If they refuse take video
Pls share & spread the word pic.twitter.com/huPj4g6cqY
— Baked Alaska™ (@bakedalaska) November 18, 2016
The #TrumpCup campaign subsequently went into overdrive.
I got my Starbucks with Trump name. 😍 he yelled Trump get your drink #TrumpCup pic.twitter.com/X8FK2b962D
— Democrats Tear 💦 (@ArantheGreat) November 18, 2016
@bakedalaska did this today. They didn't want to, said it was too political. I reminded her the campaign was over & he's our president now. pic.twitter.com/LHgi7Vqexh
— Catriona (@KittyCakes92) November 18, 2016
On Primary #ElectionDay I got a #TrumpCup
Then when I tried to #BoycottStarbucks & they wouldn't refund my $100 credit I did it @bakedalaska pic.twitter.com/78Alp8Q9fX
— PRESIDENT TRUMP🇺🇸 (@BarbieKeleigh) November 18, 2016
Some people have had less success than others — and one person reportedly had the cops called on him for pulling the stunt.
My 8 year old after being refused a #TrumpCup
"This violates article 12 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child!"
We all clapped
— Chicago Joe (@adudeinaplace2) November 18, 2016
The idea of sticking it to Starbucks by giving them cash received mixed reviews on Twitter.
The #TrumpCup "movement" shows the true idiotic nature of Trump supporters....well done though @Starbucks 💰💰💰 #idiocracy
— Ashley (@afisch01) November 18, 2016
Brilliant Provocateur: Write "Trump" on my Starbucks cup!
Barista: Oookay
BP: Now here's the money for my drink!
Barista: Sure
BP: BOOM!
— Patton Oswalt (@pattonoswalt) November 18, 2016
A Starbucks spokesperson told Mashable : "Over the years, writing customer names on cups and calling out their names has been a fun ritual in our stores.
"Rarely has it been abused or taken advantage of. We hope and trust that our customers will continue to honor that tradition. We don’t require our partners to write or call out names."
@Starbucks reaction after seeing the Trump supporters attempt at protesting while buying their coffe #TrumpCup pic.twitter.com/x54jvamJHn
— Your Yoruba Husband (@O_Tunj) November 18, 2016

posts.title: #TrumpCup: Trump fans protest Starbucks by buying coffee
posts.text:
#TrumpCup: Trump fans protest Starbucks by buying coffee Shop-in launched after Trump supporter claims barista refused to serve him By LEVI PULKKINEN, SEATTLEPI.COM STAFF Updated 4:39   Video: #TrumpCup incident CBS video 
Christmas must be in the air, because some conservatives are again protesting Starbucks. 
This time around it is all about #TrumpCup. Apparently, the Trump faithful are demanding baristas write “Trump” on their coffees because one of their number got cross with a Miami Starbucks worker on Wednesday. 
That’s right – some on the right are upset with Starbucks, so they’re buying more coffee to make their point. Think of it as an anti-boycott. 
Of a piece with the now constant, conservative rage at the Seattle-based coffee giant. 
Starbucks, through no apparent fault of its own, became a Second Amendment battleground after gun rights advocates took umbrage with gun control supporters request that Starbucks ban guns from its cafes . They took to carrying their weapons into Starbucks in protest. 
Here’s the video that sparked the latest uproar: 
A white man who said he was a Trump voter was filmed accusing a black female employee at a Starbucks in Miami of “discrimination” on November 16. According to the person who shot the clip, the man was aggravated due to a long wait for coffee.In the video, he is heard demanding his money back from a black woman at a cash register, after saying he was being treated badly because he “voted for Trump.” After telling the employee she is “garbage” and “complete trash,” a male employee scolds him, and heated words are exchanged. The man then tells the male employee, “I’ll punch you out.” The employee responds, asking the man if he wanted to “take it outside.” A few more words are exchanged before the man exits the Starbucks. Jorge de Cárdenas shot this video of the incident. He told Storyful that before he starting recording, the man had been “disparaging” the employee because of the wait. “Another customer, a young woman, had called him an asshole. Then he said ‘fuck you bitch’ to her and then the woman behind the counter told him to leave,” de Cárdenas said. Credit: Twitter/Jorge de Cárdenas via Storyful Media: Twitter/Jorge de Cárdenas via Storyful 
#TrumpCup became national news Friday as Trump supporters pushed the effort on Twitter. The Miami Herald got to it a day earlier, though, and noted the man pictured in that video, David Sanguesa, has a long history of bad behavior . And angry correspondence with the newspaper. 
“There were all those days, going back years, when he emailed the Miami Herald with rants against Cubans, women, immigrants, gays and lesbians, President Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton,” Herald writers Carli Teproff and Charles Rabin wrote in Thursday’s piece. 
Speaking with the reporters, Sanguesa apparently tried to have it both ways. According to the report, he first apologized and said he had apologized to the worker, and then claimed his attorneys wanted him to sue for racial discrimination. 
In the video, Sanguesa, who is white, can be heard berating a woman behind the counter. He calls her “garbage” and “trash” while claiming his latte was too slow in coming. 
The barista told a Miami television station she did not refuse to serve Sanguesa, who was a regular at the café. 
Neither Sangeusa’s half apology nor concerns about his mental state and history of arrests have stopped some Trump supporters from rallying to his cause. Again, by continuing to buy coffee from the business that has so offended them. 
Here’s how one Pepe the Frog-sporting Trump supporter did it: 1) Go to Starbucks & tell them your name is Trump2) If they refuse take videoPls share & spread the word pic.twitter.com/huPj4g6cqY — Baked Alaska™ (@bakedalaska) November 18, 2016 
Responding to CNN , a Starbucks spokesperson noted that baristas are not required to write customers’ names on cups. 
"Over the years, writing customer names on cups and calling out their names has been a fun ritual in our stores," a Starbucks spokesperson told CNN . "Rarely has it been abused or taken advantage of. We hope and trust that our customers will continue to honor that tradition." 
The good news for Starbucks is the actual cups have been deemed sufficiently festive this year . Though people seem too distracted to care anyway. 
Seattlepi.com reporter Levi Pulkkinen can be reached at 206-448-8348 or . Follow Levi on Twitter at twitter.com/levipulk .

posts.title: #TrumpCup campaign hits Starbucks, draws questions
posts.text:
Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed
x Share
Don't be surprised if you hear 'Trump' shouted from behind the counter at your local Starbucks. USA TODAY
Starbucks has 13 holiday red cups this year. (Photo: Starbucks.)
Donald Trump supporters are nudging Starbucks servers to announce the name of their candidate by ordering coffee under Trump's name.
It is a tradition at Starbucks that servers ask customers for their names, and when an order is ready, shout out those customers' names. Trump supporters are ordering food and drink and telling Starbucks employees their name is Trump, compelling servers to call them to the counter for their orders by shouting out "Trump!"
The campaign dubbed #TrumpCup on social media is the latest wave in what has been a contentious campaign and post-election cycle. Some media reports questioned whether the Starbucks effort was motivated by the fact that CEO Howard Schultz endorsed Trump's opponent, Hillary Clinton, for president. But creator Timothy Treadstone said the idea was actually a social experiment in First Amendment rights.
Treadstone, a 29-year-old political consultant and social media strategist from Los Angeles, told USA TODAY that he was motivated to start the campaign after seeing video on social media in which a Trump supporter attempts to give his name as Trump at a Starbucks. The audio is muffled, but it appears as if the Starbucks employee is not responding to the repeated request and that the employee then asks a coworker to call the police.
After seeing the video, Treadstone posted to his Twitter account, @bakedalaska, on Thursday night: "Operation #TrumpCup 1) Go to Starbucks & tell them your name is Trump 2) If they refuse take video Pls share & spread the word."
"This is not a protest; it's not a boycott," Treadstone said by telephone. "This is a social experiment ... This is just something we’re doing to keep Starbucks accountable. We want to help out our economy, keep people accountable and have a little fun."
Treadmill's comments were in part a response to questions that have emerged on social media in which members of the public asked about the effectiveness of a campaign that would bring more, not less, business to Starbucks.
Twitter user Quote: : "So let me get this straight, you're going to protest against a company by giving them money?"
Tweeted @CaptainsLog2016: "I don't think Trumpkins have thought this whole #TrumpCup through. If you have to buy a product form the place you're boycotting... #FAIL."
Starbucks released a statement regarding #TrumpCup: "Over the years, writing customer names on cups and calling out their names has been a fun ritual in our stores. Rarely has it been abused or taken advantage of. We hope and trust that our customers will continue to honor that tradition. We don't require our partners to write or call out names."
